column9: This is an important update of the entry for BC Diabetes. They now provide, on referral, NO CHARGE, Zoom assistance to residents of any province except Quebec! (They have agreements to bill your provinces health system.) They are fully up-to-speed on Loop and iAPS and Nightscout and have a systematic process to efficiently advise new or experienced DIYAPS T1Ds. Finally, a Canadian endo that embraces DIYAPS. Highly recommended. *If you decide to use BCD, please rely on them for your primary support for Loop.

"Runs BC's largest diabetes clinic, which offers BCDLoop.app and Nightscout server to patients of the clinic, installable either in clinic or remotely via TestFlight. Zoom consultations available to both to local and remote BC patients. http://bcdiabetes.ca/" *If you decide to use BCD, please rely on them for your primary support for Loop.

column9: Probably the 6th or 7th doctor I worked with since I was diagnosed - and hopefully the last. My visits are almost always over an hour, whether online or in-person (I live 500km away and still won't change him). He is booked for months ahead but will always find time to pick up the phone, text back, or squeeze you in.

She was an hour and fifteen minutes late, only spoke to my boyfriend (she didn't look at me, the patient, even once), she looked HORRIFIED when I said I wanted to start the Omnipod Dash and Dexcom G6 so I could loop, and it's a miracle I left there with any prescriptions because she was so unhelpful. column9: She has supported our goals for low Al's and time in range 4.6-5.5 fir 5 years team mgmt never needed her assistance just came in wrote scripts and was pleasant and left. My 18 year old recently took over mgmt and she saw his A1C rise to 5.7 with some spikes to 200 she kindly said without any malice I see you are taking the reigns. "Have you been pre bolusing as much" I knew this was the issue but she spotted it immediately and was great to work with him never chastising but reminded him he can do better if he wants to even though that was a great A1C she also tells him not to stress over diabetes etc. She doesn't expect everyone to do that but knew he knew how. So I feel like she can give very individualized attention. Anything medicine wise or care plan wise I have asked for she has done. They can access all reports sent digitally or are fine with print outs however you wish.

column9: Entire team of diabetes educators lives with T1D and the majority use LOOP as their own treatment. Additional info: "We have the flexibility and expertise to really help these folks through just about every step in the process. Some require considerable education and fine-tuning before getting started, while others are ready to roll almost immediately. And for those using Loop, we can always help with fine-tuning the settings and making safe/effective use of all the advanced features and parameters that are buried within the app." Some insurance plans cover the cost of telemed visits. (Medicare paid 50% after appealing their first decision.)

column9: Dr. Bryant has been there for us since day one, when my daughter was diagnosed with T1D while in DKA at McLane Children's Hospital PICU. We see him every three months for the last 8 years now, and he's always kind, compassionate, and answers our questions thoughtfully and without judgement. He never speaks down to you, and loves to emphasize that you, the parent, know your child's diabetes best, and he's there to help you along the way. He also has a great team with two CDCESs and a nutritionist as well. Dr. Bryant also supported us in our desire to use DIY Loop, and as a result, my daughter's A1c has been <6% for over three years now.
